newsitem.title: USA: U.S. non-committal on Lebed dismissal.
newsitem.headline: U.S. non-committal on Lebed dismissal.

text.p: The United States on Thursday took no official position on the dismissal of Russian security chief Alexander Lebed, calling it an internal Russian matter.
"The U.S. has no comment. It is an internal affair of the Russian government and the Russian people," State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said in a statement to reporters.
A senior White House official said Russian President Boris Yeltsin had "acted in accordance with his constitutional perogatives" in firing Lebed.
Asked if the United States had advance notice of the move, the official, who asked not to be identified, said: "I am not aware of any."
The United States has had mixed feelings about Lebed, a reserve general who scored a strong 15 per cent in the first round of Russia's presidential election last June.

Washington welcomed Lebed's success in negotiating an end to fighting in Chechnya, and also praised comments he made during a visit to Brussels this month which appeared to take a flexible view of NATO expansion.
But U.S. officials have also seen him as something of a loose cannon and have condemned comments he made which they said were hostile to religious groups including Jews and Roman Catholics.
In Moscow, U.S. Defence Secretary William Perry said the sacking of Lebed would not change the deepening security relationship between Washington and Moscow.

"The relationship between Mr. Lebed and U.S. officials never really had a chance to develop, and so I don't see any fundamental change in the U.S.-Russian relationship in terms of this announcement," Perry told reporters in response to questions after Yeltsin publicly sacked his security chief.
Perry, on a three-day visit to Russia, said he had cancelled a meeting with Lebed at the last minute late on Thursday because he was aware "of the problems that Lebed was having with the government."
"I could not forecast this particular outcome, but it seemed unwise to go ahead and schedule that meeting and so we did not schedule it," Perry said.
"Our security relationship will proceed just as it has been proceeding," he added.
